awd_titl_txt: CIF21 DIBBs: PD: Enhancing and Personalizing Educational Resources through Tools for Experimentation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project would automate the creation and data analysis of randomized controlled experiments (RCEs).   RCEs are question sets designed and delivered to teachers and students in a classroom setting, and can be used to compare alternative educational strategies. This effort builds on an existing educational platform (ASSISTments) developed by the Principal Investigator, and uses a template-based approach to increase the efficiency and reliability of conducting educational research.  The goal is to lower the barriers to creating and learning from randomized controlled experiments. The project has the potential to facilitate large-scale learning in education research, reaching hundreds of schools and thousands of students.

The project builds upon two prior developments by this team.  
  -  ASSISTments is an online learning platform originally designed to provide students with assistance and teachers with assessments (establishing the moniker).  The system is used primarily as an online tutoring system for middle or secondary education, supporting the delivery, collection, and grading of classwork and homework, providing immediate feedback for students and explicit reporting for teachers.  To date, 24 randomized controlled experiments comparing educational strategies have been published using this platform.  
  -  In addition, AssistmentsTestBed.org is a testbed developed by the PI and his group under a separate NSF grant (#1440753), to identify best practices in education and allow other researchers to propose and run their own studies leveraging ASSISTments as a shared scientific instrument through this testbed.  Beneficiaries include education researchers, teachers, and students, with the existing tool being used in over 500 schools and in the education of over 50,000 students.  
The current project improves two components of the infrastructure that have been resource-intensive bottlenecks in prior research.    One task automates the process of study creation and data analysis, through development of a Template Tool that enables studies within ASSISTments.  A second task automates statistical analyses and improves usability of the existing data reporting tool (Assessment of Learning Infrastructure, or ALI).  The improvements will be achieved, in part, by applying educational data mining algorithms (i.e., deep knowledge tracing) on student data collected before, during, and after experimentation.  These analytics will provide researchers with covariates that will significantly improve the agenda of personalizing education.  The resulting capability will assist researchers as they design and deliver question sets to teachers and students in a classroom setting, increase the efficiency and reliability of conducting educational research at scale, and streamline the research processes.

This award by the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure is jointly supported by the NSF Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings.

por.por_cntn:
This DIBBs project, “Enhancing and Personalizing Educational Resources through Tools for Experimentation,” was an effort by the ASSISTments team at Worcester Polytechnic Institute to strengthen educational research. The goal of this project was to make it easier to conduct randomized controlled experiments (RCEs) on learning interventions at scale by using automated processes in an online learning environment. The purpose behind this work was to cut costs, eliminate obstacles commonly experienced by educational researchers, and increase experimental efficiency through enhanced capacity for rapid iteration by means of developing what we initially proposed as the “Template Tool” within ASSISTments, an online learning platform for K-12 mathematics.


As this project grew in scope we realized that the needs of researchers creating RCEs in ASSISTments were extensive and that the limited selection of experimental designs made possible by the Template Tool would not fulfill our long term goals for the platform. We supplemented our DIBBs funding with additional funds from Schmidt Futures and set out to develop a unique standalone application that now hosts much of the original Template Tool’s functionality. The resulting application, E-TRIALS (an Ed Tech Research Infrastructure to Advance Learning Science), offers a robust UI for the development, deployment, and dissemination of RCEs, and includes a finalized, interactive version of the Template Tool that helps users toggle experimental “modules” (i.e., inclusion of a pretest) while creating their studies. The app shows users a preview of the experimental design they are implementing and keeps all content selection and manipulation within the tool, creating a more user friendly experience. The app also incorporates redeveloped reporting protocol (previously known as the Assessment of Learning Infrastructure) and automated analyses for admin use. Our original goals with the Template Tool, made possible by DIBBs, played a significant role in helping to streamline the process of research within ASSISTments and ultimately resulted in the development of E-TRIALS; a Beta of the E-TRIALS application launched in Summer 2021 and is currently undergoing formal user testing (https://etrials.assistments.org/#/login). 


Significant results of this project include the additional funding procured for extending the idea of the Template Tool into a fully formed application, E-TRIALS. The project also played a critical role in training multiple graduate and undergraduate students at WPI and has supported the work of at least 42 researchers working with ASSISTments. We continue to strive for improvements to the experimental design capabilities of E-TRIALS, using lessons learned from the experiences of real researchers as we iterate on the E-TRIALS application to ensure the longevity of the initial work undertaken by this DIBBs project. E-TRIALS will focus on centralizing and strengthening all elements of research within ASSISTments, making it a leading resource for scaled educational research. The results of our DIBBs work and ongoing efforts are on track to offer opportunities for interdisciplinary growth through educational research at scale.


This DIBBs project has also impacted the educational data mining community. Ongoing tangential research has isolated independent variables in RCEs that may serve as predictors in longitudinal data mining analyses or analyses that consider multiple studies simultaneously. Prior to implementation of the Template Tool, researchers’ studies were logged in detail and categorized based on various characteristics such as targeted skill, content area, format of content presentation (e.g., image, text, interactive object), type of feedback/assistance/scaffolding (e.g., text, video), etc. This library of study content was recently redeveloped into a research database that stores information about every study ever conducted in ASSISTments, allowing the WPI team to offer stronger support to users while helping to strengthen documentation of outcomes. PI Heffernan has hosted multiple large-scale datamining competitions throughout the duration of this project, and the WPI team recently produced the biggest corpus of experimental data from ASSISTments to date, including data from 104 RCEs, that will continue to advance this community.


The Intellectual merit of this work includes the new E-TRIALS informational site (www.etrialstestbed.org), which supports dissemination of all materials related to the E-TRIALS application including protocol, resources, and featured works. At least 10 papers have already been disseminated without PI or CoPI involvement, and the ongoing projects of 30 research teams will undoubtedly expand upon the direct intellectual merit of this work in the near future.


Broader impact of this work can be measured in the versatile demographic spread of researchers working with E-TRIALS and ASSISTments. Our research cohorts have included international researchers as well as those working to serve underprivileged communities. In addition, research content developed within ASSISTments helps to improve the learning experience of all students using the platform and specifically offering continued impact for students in opportunity zones. 


We proudly consider this DIBBs project as the origin of a larger and potentially extremely impactful area of work and we look forward to future outcomes made possible by this project.
